entry.title: Sales order creation from cxml document
entry.content:
Hello,

We have one customer who is using a P2P solution which is able to send his purchase order as PO Cxml message. The objective is to create a sales document (sales order or sales quotation #S4/HANA SD#) using this cxml document.

I know we can deliver using ABAP code but I didn't find any standard way to proceed. I have even looked into SAP Business Network but resources related to sell side is not clear. 

Have I missed something ?

entry.title: Re: Automatic Payment Run Identification in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Jessica,

In the document generated for the payment e.g. 2000000xxx will have the following information in the header text: 20251112-RUN05, where the payment run date is the date 12th of Nov 2025 and run ID is RUN05. This is system generated string in the document generated during payment run. Hope this helps you to identify the string based which you can reconcile the payments. Let us know if helps or you have further query.

Regards.

entry.title: RES1 smaller than accrual REA2 same value as RES1
entry.content:
We are having Z Conditions :

 

Problem is that payout will be smaller than the builded accrual but we won't balance the complete accrual value

Tried to use the REA5 (YEA5) but then the deducted value is double so on this case I will payout 5 â‚¬ the REA2(YRA4) is the complete amount of 197,40 and the YEA5 is the accrual minus 2*5 â‚¬ do left in the accrual account 187,40 from my opinion this is not correct. Does anybody have a solution or explanation for me?

entry.title: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Motivation

In my previous blog I explained the Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting and when it needs adjustment by customers.

In this blog I will explain how to copy and adjust the underlying analytical queries and adjust the selection to prepare them for a customized review booklet. It is for key users and technical consultants.

Since we did enhancements in the booklet with SAP Cloud ERP 2602, as announced in the previous blog, we had to create new analytical queries, which I will already use in my screenshots. I recommend to wait for 2602 to do the adjustments, so you already have the new features for several company codes and currencies in your customized booklet.

Copying the SAP delivered queries

Launch the App â€œCustom Analytical Queries and Servicesâ€ (F1572A) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST. Click on the link â€œManage Queriesâ€. In the next screen click the button â€œCopyâ€.

Figure 1: Copy the first SAP delivered query 

In the pop-up, name your custom query, e.g. â€œYY1_CUSTCOMPMARGâ€ and as the source query specify â€œC_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2â€ (for 2602 release, in 2508 it would be C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY).

This query is used on the â€œCompany Margin (Full Year)â€ page group of the booklet.

Click â€œOKâ€ and on the next screen give your new customer query a name, e.g. â€œCompany Margin Custom Queryâ€.

Figure 2: Name custom query

 Then click on the â€œFieldsâ€ tab.

Figure 3: Optionally add a remove fields

Here you can optionally add or remove fields in the query to be used or not in the booklet.

The list of available fields comes from the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 (in 2602, or I_CompanyMarginCube in 2508) and can only be changed by SAP.

If you also want the â€œYear-to-Dateâ€, â€œFiscal Quarterâ€ or â€œFiscal Periodâ€ comparison page groups, which are available in the SAP delivered booklet, in you customized booklet, please repeat the steps above for the SAP delivered query â€œC_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY_2â€ (in 2602, or C_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY in 2508) after completing the following steps for the first query.

 

Figure 4: Copy the second SAP delivered query 

 

Adjusting the selection criteria in the custom query

Next click on the tab â€œModelâ€. You will see the list of measures (or key figures) used in the booklet.

As explained in the previous blog, you need to adjust the selection of Read Key Figures, if you do not use the SAP best practices Functional Areas.

But letâ€™s first see the usage of the semantic tags on the Read Key Figures.

Select e.g. the measure â€œBilled Revenue (technical name â€œBilledRevenueAmntInDispCrryâ€). Then turn on â€œSematic Tagâ€ selection criteria. 

Figure 5: Sematic Tag selection of Read Key Figure

 You will see, that the semantic tag â€œBILL_REVâ€ is used to read billed revenues. Please do not change this.

Now you can go through the list of Read Key Figures to decide, where the Functional Area selection needs to be adjusted.

Figure 6: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

 As an example, letâ€™s take â€œCost of Goods Sold â€“ Variableâ€ (technical name â€œVariableCOGSAmntInDispCrryâ€). Select the measure from the list and activate â€œFunctional Areaâ€ selection criteria. 

Figure 7: Change Functional Area selection for COGS

 You see the SAP best practices Functional Areas YB18 (Cost of Goods Sold) and YB25 (Consulting/Services) are used to read COGS for product or service centric business processes.

You can now change them to the ones you use in your respective sales scenarios.

Figure 8: Add Functional Area selection

 The same applies for the measure â€œCost of Goods Sold â€“ Fixedâ€ (technical name â€œFxdCOGSAmtInDspCrcyâ€.

 As another example letâ€™s take the measure â€œAdministration Overheadâ€ (technical name â€œAdminOverheadAmtInDspCrcyâ€).

In the SAP delivered query the Functional Area YB40 is used for Administration. You can now replace with your own.

Figure 9: Replace Functional Area selection

Please complete this task for all measures, which need adjustment of Functional Area.

If you have copied the query for the period comparison pages, please do the same there. It contains the same measure structure.

 

Optional: Change default values for filters and parameters

The query also contains same default values for general selection in the booklet. You can optionally change them, so the apply for all users in your customized booklet.

For example, if you want to use your own Financial Statement Version (please see previous blog), go on the tab â€œParametersâ€, select the â€œFinancial Statement Versionâ€ and change the default value. 

Figure 10: Change default values of parameters

 Please note, that the FSV can stay a filter in the booklet and can later be changed by an end user again.

 Another example is to change the default value of the global filter â€œCurrency Fieldâ€, which is introduced in 2602.

Go on the tab â€œFilterâ€ and select â€œCurrency Fieldâ€. The default value is Company Code Currency (CCC). You can change e.g. to Global Currency (GC).

Figure 11: Change default values of filters 

 

Check and publish your custom queries

In the next step please go to the tab â€œLogsâ€ and click the button â€œCheckâ€.

No errors should appear in the logs and you can click â€œPublishâ€.

Figure 12: Publish custom query

 Please repeat for second query.

 

Create InA Service with both customer queries

The custom booklet will require an InA Service which contain the custom queries.

To create it, go back to the start page of the App â€œCustom Analytical Queries and Servicesâ€ (F1572A) and click â€œManage InA Servicesâ€, then click â€œCreateâ€.

Figure 13: Create custom InA Service

 Give it a name, a label and click â€œOKâ€.

Next add your custom queries to it with â€œAdd queryâ€ and publish the service. 

Figure 14: Add custom queries

 

Create custom review booklet

You can now create your own review booklet based on the InA Service.

Please launch the App â€œManage KPIs and Reportsâ€ (F2814) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.

Select the tab â€œReview Bookletsâ€ and click â€œCreateâ€. 

Figure 15: Create review booklet.

Give it an ID, a name and description and click â€œCreateâ€. 

Figure 16: Open configuration for custom review booklet

 Now click â€œOpen Configurationâ€ to access the review booklet designer. On the tab â€œGeneralâ€ specify your custom Ina Service. 

Figure 17: Add custom Ina Service in custom review booklet

 Then click â€œGenerate Contentâ€, select your custom queries and click â€œGenerateâ€. 

Figure 18: Generate booklet content for customer queries

This will prepare the data providers for the booklet.

You now can go through the booklet designer and customize your pages groups, pages, row and column sets, etc.

Please see the SAP help how to work with the review booklet designer: Configuring a Review Booklet

This is a manual step, which canâ€™t be avoided by coping the SAP delivered review booklet, since all settings in the review booklet designer depend on the used queries.

You can however have a look at the SAP delivered booklet as a reference how to configure yours.

Figure 19: Reference Business Pages in SAP delivered booklet

 

Conclusion

You now know, how to customize a query and create a custom review booklet on top of it.

With this know-how you can also customize other SAP delivered review booklets.

The article can also give you an idea, how to create your complete own custom analytical queries, using developer extensibility. This is more advanced and would allow you to create an own contribution margin structure with more than 3 levels and different key figures for revenues and costs.

You can also create review booklet on top of self-developed custom analytical queries.

entry.title: Re: Sales order creation from cxml document
entry.content:
@Meriadec wrote:

Hello,

We have one customer who is using a P2P solution which is able to send his purchase order as PO Cxml message. The objective is to create a sales document (sales order or sales quotation #S4/HANA SD#) using this cxml document.

I know we can deliver using ABAP code but I didn't find any standard way to proceed. I have even looked into SAP Business Network but resources related to sell side is not clear. 

Have I missed something ?

Hello @Meriadec,
Thereâ€™s no standard S/4HANA SD function to directly consume cXML POs into sales orders â€” it requires custom integration. Typically youâ€™d parse the cXML via middleware (SAP CPI/PI) or ABAP service, then map to SD BAPIs/IDocs (e.g. `ORDERS05`). SAP Business Network focuses on buyâ€‘side; for sellâ€‘side you need custom mapping or 3rdâ€‘party connectors.

Best Regards,
Mabel Brown

entry.title: Get to know SAPâ€™s educational offerings for academia
entry.content:
SAP offers an integrated suite of solutions that help organizations of all sizes and industries run their entire businessâ€”from finance and supply chain to customer experience and sustainability. The SAP University Alliances portfolio of academic offerings mirror the SAP solution portfolio, providing access to the latest SAP technologies and academically relevant content to lecturers in disciplines across business, information systems, engineering and computer science. The portfolio helps lecturers connect theory to practice in a way that meets their academic need, whether it is content supporting a full semester course or smaller chunks of content students can complete outside of class in a flipped classroom model.

The challenge (and opportunity!) is to identify the offerings that support your own classroom learning objectives and teaching style. To make our portfolio easier to understand and consume, weâ€™ve started to restructure and simplify. Weâ€™ve aligned our offerings into a framework that features both no cost resources and learning experiences direct to lecturers around the world plus the low-cost offers with premium support from our University Competence Centers (UCCs) / Academic Competence Centers (UCCs) and other academic partners that have anchored our portfolio for more than 25 years.

Offerings are now clustered into four topic areas, each lead by a teaching offering manager (TOM) that can connect the dots between the academic topic and relevant SAP solution(s).

The four topic areas are:

  1. Business Process Management
    - Executing, modeling and transforming business processes from sales to purchasing, production, human resources and financial reporting

  2. Data Science & Analytics
    - Develop future data analysts / data architects, and data literacy for all students

  3. App Development & Coding
    - low-code and pro-code development, AI and other critical topics tomorrowâ€™s technology leaders need experience with

  4. Computing Education
    - introduces computer science concepts and provide a first programming experience with the visual, block-based Snap! Programming language

Announcing!  New portfolio blog series

To ensure our academic community is always in the loop with new and updated offerings, we are launching this new blog series. Each topic leader has published their first blog providing a big picture introduction to the topic area and its key offerings, best practices shared by lecturers, how to get started, content in the pipeline and much more.  Each quarter they will share the latest updates so you can start exploring the new / updated resources and plan your classroom activities.

Call to Action:  Join the discussion!

Read the topic area blogs, subscribe and join the discussion.  Post your questions and ideas. Share your experiences and best practices.  Let us know how we can help you be successful using SAP in the classroom!

entry.title: Re: Output Management - How to send emails to mail-addres...
entry.content:
Hello @SCHNEIDERT

Thank you for your question

You are correct, no released CDS view provides exactly what you described. So yes, the approach is to create a Custom CDS View based on standard data.

First, I would suggest you avoid using I_BPContactToFuncAndDept unless you need to filter function or department. It might be an overkill just for emails and could introduce duplicates which you already observed.

Second, using I_BPRelationship_2 provides relationship between Customer and Contact Person. The I_BusinessPartnerContactAddress will provide the actual email address which you can then join using the BusinessPartner2 from I_BPRelationship_2

Third, you are getting duplicates probably because some of your BPs have multiple address versions for each valid date, you did not apply StandardAddress filter or you are joining both directions of the BP1 to BP2 relationship. I suggest you only include BUR001 Contact Person, IsStandardAddress and filter out ValidTo entries.

Below are steps you can consider in your tenant:

Open your Custom CDS View app, create a new

Set the primary data source as shown in the screen below

Add Business partner as an associated data source.

Make use of: I_BusinessPartnerAddress and thereafter, join I_BPCompanRelationshipVH. BusinessPartner2=I_BusinessPartnerAddress.BusinessPartener.  Make sure you IsStandardAddress is set to true.

Then publish your CDS View.

You can test it with the Custom Analytical Queries

The YY1_I_BPRelationship_2 works same for your use case. You can select fields like BP1, BP2, Emailaddress, Relationship Category. You may also add filters as mentioned earlier.

A Pseudo CDS View code could look like this:

Finally, regarding your question on how the Code in the BAdI would look like, I do not have the authorisation in the system to provide such information. You can however, implement the BAdI APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS in the output Parameter Determination.

To summarise:

  • Yes, you need a Custom CDS View
  • Use the BP2 plus BPContactAddress as your base
  • Use filtering to avoid duplicates
  • In your BAdI, select business partner as a selection from your CDS view

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: S4HC Public Crosscompany Flow CO Issue (Margin analysis by customer not available at group level)
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We are implementing S4HC Public to a Industrial Food company. They have a manufacturing company (2000) and a trading company (3000). They have a crosscompany process, in which the shipment is done from 2000 and the billing from 3000, so there is an internal billing with a margin because of legal transfer price requirements. Once the flow is done and the accounting documents are registered, the analytical PL by company code is shown in the screenshot attached. 

The problem we find is that the customer filled in the PSG of the expense registered in 3000 (internal billing) is the final customer instead of the group customer (3000), whereas the COGS from the shipment from 2000 has the group customer (3000) instead of the final customer. This standard behaviour of the system prevents the client to analyze the actual margin by customer at group level skipping the internal billing, since the revenue is allocated to the final customer in the PSG, but the COGS from the shipment is allocated to the group customer (3000).

- Implementing transfer pricing is not an option.

- Changing the invoice type from INVOICE02 to INVOICE01 in the IDOC, so that internal billing expense is allocated to the group customer (3000) in the PSG is not allowed in S4HC Public.

- PSG derivation customizing point (which would resolve our problem, since we could change the customer in the PSG according to many conditions and rules) is not available in S4HC Public. Instead we have a very limited app (Manage Substitution and Validation Rules) in which, for the Margin Analysis context, we only have available PSG characteristics as conditions (which are not useful for this case) and fields like gl account or movement type (needed for doing the derivation correctly) are not available.

WHAT CAN WE DO? Is there any custom logic we can use for an "advanced PSG characteristic sustitution"? 

Thanks. Regards,

entry.title: Re: How to avoid errors when configuring mandatory event reason for Onboarding?
entry.content:
Is anyone having an issue with Rehire Event reason?

Our Rehire cases are triggering an error - You cannot create a job information record without the hire record for user. The first job information record must be the hire record

As event reason is mandatory in offer, when onboarding is initiated and upon submission of the Review New Hire data step, the error is triggered - You cannot create a job information record without the hire record for user. The first job information record must be the hire record

entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities
entry.content:
Since 1H 2025, SAP has released the new Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities. The purpose of this blog is to describe it, showcase it in action, and highlight its main features beyond what the official documentation covers.

 

What Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities is NOT

Before diving in let's clarify what Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA) is not: do not confuse it with the previous version called Payroll Control Center: Process Management.

Although both are related and focused on the same process they are different solutions with a different approach, being PCC-MPA far more powerful and easier to configure. It includes all the functionalities of its predecessor, plus much more.

 

What's Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities

Now, let's define what it really is. Here a definition extracted from the official guide (quoted verbatim; all copied text in this blog is in italic):

The Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activitiesâ€‹ solution enables business users to manage a complete payroll cycle from start to end, not just running the payroll calculation, but all payroll activities that are necessary (for example, all statutory reporting, internal reporting, and so on).

In Manage Payroll Activities, the payroll activity list provides a graphical overview of all payroll activities in a graph. From this graph, the payroll manager can already get a good understanding of the relationship between the different payroll activities and the quality of the overall payroll cycle.

The payroll manager clicks a payroll activity to investigate its details, for example, a Monitoring activity. A monitoring activity allows users to get early insight into the payroll data quality.

Clicking a step opens a customizable dashboard that has been configured by the configuration user and shows the relevant information that enables the payroll manager to judge if their payroll data quality is good.

The payroll manager can click a dashboard card to see further details. They can drill down to the details they want (which can be customized). The payroll manager can check the open alerts, check who is working on the alerts, and further drill down to the details of an alert to get an understanding of its complexity.

In the Manage Alerts app, the payroll administrators can do some detailed analysis of why an employee has a specific problem. The app provides a dashboard view where the payroll administrators can get a quick understanding of the situation. The payroll administrator can click a dashboard card to see further details. They can drill down to the details they want based on the configuration.

 

Sounds great, right?

Before we get into it, let's review the prerequisites.

 

Prerequisites

As pointed out here, these are its prerequisites:

  • You have implemented your payroll.
  • Your payroll is based on SAP Human Capital Management for SAP S/4 HANA solutions.
  • If you are implementing SAP preferred payroll solution, that is SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll, you must to enable it in Provisioning selecting Enable Payroll Control Center checkbox.

Common question:  Does it work in other SAP Human Capital Management for SAP S/4 HANA solutions, such as Private Cloud Edition? 

Answer: Yes, but future enhancements and new features related to PCC-MPA, may be exclusive to SAP's preferred solution: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll. That is why all the references in this guide to official documentation point to it. 

 

Key concepts

Here a list of the most important objects in the solution:

  • action: A dynamic URL that can generate the value at run time and points to a link where payroll administrators or payroll manager can update employees' master data or check further details.
  • activity: The sequence of all steps that are required to execute payroll and all related activities (for example, legal reporting) for a specific entity.
  • activity list: The combination of one or more relevant payroll activities in a complete payroll cycle.
  • analytics designer: Program output, table layout, simple form of label-value pairs, or different types of charts to provide details for a validation rule or step execution.
  • step: A single step within a payroll activity.
  • policy: A set of validation rules grouped according to your needs. A policy helps you to achieve payroll compliance.
  • validation rule: A check function executed by the system to identify compliance violations or potential risks.

 

Solution Insights

Let's see it in action!

 

1. Configure your Payroll Activities

Use a graphical and user-friendly configuration tool to set define payroll activities tailored to your specific process.

You will be able to define your process, with all the activities and steps, setting the prerequisites, automating them when possible, define run periods and much more:

 

It is worth to mention that any report in your backend would be accessible to the PCC-MPA, that means that even your custom reports can be included without extra coding.

 

2. Plan your Payroll Activities

Once configured, you only need to start a new recurrence and the entire payroll process, with all the activities and their steps, will be ready to run:

 

 

3. Run and Monitor your Payroll 

Now the fun begins!

Run each step/activity and view its results with the charts, program outputs,... as you customized, tracking your process graphically in real time.

Also the monitor activity will show the preconfigured alerts that the system has calculated proactively:

 

 

4. Alerts Resolution

Each alert includes its own detailed insights: charts, employee data, lists, ... even specific resolution guides that you have set up beforehand to simplify administrators' tasks. They will be able to resolve any issue without leaving the Payroll Control Center!

 

 

 

What's next

Did you like it? Stay tuned, more updates coming soon!

entry.title: Sales Price Rounding Issue S4 HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We have a customer requirement Regard to rounding off Price in S4 HANA Public cloud as given below:

Product Selling Price = Base Price * Margin

Base Price (ZPR0) at Material level = Rs. 9.94/KG

Selling Margin at Product Group Level (ZPRM) = 5%

As per Standard Calculation:

Consider order Quantity = 3500

Condition Value (ZPR0) = 3500*9.94 = Rs. 34,790.00

Condition Value (ZPRM) = 34790*0.05 = 1739.50

Gross Condition Value = 34790+1739.50 = 36529.50

Gross Condition Amount = 36529.50/3500 = 10.437 = 10.44 (Round off 2 decimal)

Business Requirement:

Gross Condition Amount = 9.94+(9.94*5%) = 10.44 (Round off 2 decimal)

Gross Condition Value = 10.44 * 3500 = Rs. 36,540

We have achieved business requirement using pricing routine (Extension Point: PRCG_DOC_ITEM_CONDITION_AMOUNT) for the Gross amount to override the standard calculation. But subsequent calculation for additional conditions, Tax calculation and Final Net Value it is still considering the Gross Amount from standard calculation. Any suggestion to address this?

entry.content:
Hello experts,

I am configuring a stock transfer order between plants in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Both plants are WM-managed warehouses, and the process requires moving Handling Unit (HU) numbers from one warehouse to another.

While reviewing the Implementation Activities, I cannot find any configuration point where it is possible to define a confirmation control key per document type, similar to what exists in on-premise systems under Define Order Confirmation for Delivery.

In the Plant related Business Partner settings , I have maintained the confirmation key as Inbound Delivery (0004). However, when creating a stock transfer order in ME21N with document type UB, the confirmation field is still empty.

Does anyone know:

  • Where this can be configured in Public Cloud?

  • Or if it is even possible to default the confirmation control key to Inbound Delivery for stock transfer orders?

Any guidance or confirmation of limitations in Public Cloud would be appreciated. I've checked sap note 2436023, and it not apply to Public.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: How can finance and accounting students better unders...
entry.content:
Excellent question Johnson!

To bridge the above gap, you need to understand the SAP objects and its functional/business 'objective' within the framework of SAP Process and then correlate this with the SAP agnostic finance process.  This is easy for some of some of the objects like cost center, profit center or G/L Accounts for that matter. When we go to more complex objects like ledger, BOM, Sales Order and Purchase orders then it becomes challenging and that is the fun in learning SAP. In a nutshell: keep the flow in the mind. Finance process -> SAP Process -> Various SAP object that build this process -> how do they come together to stitch the bigger goal. Each object play a vital role: this can also be compared with the OOPS concept (as might have read in JAVA). SAP 'abstracts' every finance objects into a 'type' and then build the process using these object types. Always ask yourself, what is the role of this object in the whole process and how does it relate with the other objects. This concept will help you to marry the process and configurable objects. 

Enjoy learning.  Cheers!

entry.title: Deep Dive: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
This blog post was co-authored with @Cielo_SanabriaRuiz & @Sebastian1611 

Sustainability is no longer just about carbon emissions - itâ€™s about understanding the full environmental impact of business operations along the value chain. With the next phase of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the solution expands from a pure carbon tool to a broader environmental footprint platform: In addition to detailed analysis of greenhouse gas emissions â€“ including fossil, biogenic, and removed emissions â€“ you can now calculate and analyze your organizationâ€™s impact across a wider range of areas, such as land use , energy, waste, and resource depletion. This allows you to meet diverse reporting standards and drive operational decisions beyond decarbonization alone.

In this blog post, weâ€™ll provide you an introduction into the topic and a guided walk-through of the implementation process for multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Youâ€™ll see how to configure your system, manage the relevant data, and run calculations so you can unlock richer, decision-ready sustainability insights.

  • Introduction
  • Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories
  • Manage Source Data
  • Manage Footprint Settings
  • Manage Emission Factors
  • Model Footprint Parameters
  • Manage Periodic Data
  • Manage Footprint Calculations
  • Analyze Footprints
  • Communicate Footprints
  • Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub
  • Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

Introduction

What has changed

Since its initial release, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management has focused on calculating accurate product and corporate carbon footprints based on actual business data from SAP ERP and other sources. With the latest updates, this calculation engine now covers additional environmental impact categories so that you can monitor a wider range of environmental pressures using the same data foundation, governance model, and auditability:

Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

What multi-impact categories mean

Multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management represent separate â€œlensesâ€ on how business activities put pressure on different parts of the Earth system, all calculated on the same data foundation. This aligns well with the planetary boundaries concept, where climate change is only one boundary among several others such as biosphere integrity, land-system change, and biogeochemical flows that together define a safe operating space for humanity.

Instead of focusing on a single metric like carbon, multiâ€‘impact categories let you translate your operational data into a set of environmental pressure indicators that mirror those planetary boundaries dimensions. In practice, this means that for every relevant activity or product, you can see not only its contribution to climate change but also how it stresses other Earth-system limits, helping you understand whether improvements in one area inadvertently push another boundary closer to its threshold.â€‹ By structuring these indicators as configurable categories in the footprint model, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management becomes a bridge between planetary science and enterprise data, turning abstract boundary concepts into concrete KPIs based on your ERP data.

Why this matters for reporting

By going beyond carbon, you can align one consistent footprint dataset with multiple regulatory and voluntary frameworks, including emerging requirements from the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) or Science-Based Targets Initiativeâ€™s Forests, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance, that increasingly demand broader environmental indicators. This reduces the need for parallel tools and spreadsheet workarounds, and helps sustainability, finance, and controlling teams work from synchronized, audit-ready numbers when preparing disclosures and customer requests.â€‹

A structured multi-impact model also strengthens the credibility of reported data, because the same calculation logic and master data serve both internal and external views. That consistency is crucial when environmental performance becomes a criterion in financing, procurement, and customer negotiations.

Why this matters for decisions

When multi-impact indicators sit next to financial and operational KPIs, sustainability data moves from a separate reporting stream into the core of how you evaluate trade-offs and investment cases. This richer impact picture helps identify where reducing environmental pressure also boosts efficiency, resilience, and brand value, and where hidden risks accumulate if planetary boundaries are ignored.â€‹

In this way, multi-impact categories support a shift from compliance-driven reporting to performance-driven steering, where sustainability becomes a dimension of competitiveness and innovation. These updates are a concrete step in SAPâ€™s broader vision to transform sustainability data into a catalyst for long-term business value rather than a pure cost of doing business.

How one calculation serves many requirements

In SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the integration and calculation setup stays exactly the same as before: You still reuse your ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre-delivered emission factors, and run one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that this familiar approach now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so the same activity data and methods can serve a growing list of corporate and product-level requirements without extra integration projects or parallel calculation logic.

Footprint Calculation Concept in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories

The overall workflow remains similar to a standard carbon footprint calculation, but with crucial distinctions in steps where you specify and assign your desired impact categories and their corresponding factors:

  • Manage Source Data: Prepare foundational data.
  • Manage Footprint Settings: Configure how footprints are calculated, including impact categories.
  • Manage Emission Factors: Define impact factors for all chosen categories and link them to purchased products.
  • Model Footprint Parameters: Refine specific calculation models (e.g., energy flow, allocations).
  • Manage Periodic Data: Input business transactional data for the calculation period.
  • Manage Footprint Calculations: Execute the footprint calculation across all selected impact categories.
  • Analyze Footprints: Review and analyze on the multi-category results on different aggregation levels.
  • Communicate Footprints: Send your calculated environmental footprints to other applications.

 

Manage Source Data

The foundational master data required for environmental impact calculations is uploaded using the Import Master Data application. There are no changes to this app, for details see: Import Master Data.

 

Manage Footprint Settings

To tailor the calculation process, select your desired configuration variant using the Manage Calculation Variants app. You can either opt for the DEFAULT variant or configure a new one. Calculation variants define various parameters, such as allocation rules and Scope 2 calculation methods, which are fundamental to the overall footprint calculation. It is important to understand how these settings influence the results across all selected impact categories to ensure consistency and accuracy. See Manage Calculation Variants for more information.

Next, go to the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app to define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This is a critical step when expanding beyond pure product carbon footprints (PCFs) and corporate carbon footprints (CCFs). When creating a footprint inventory scope, you can select up to ten impact categories for a single scope, including Climate Change which is always mandatory. If you enable the Accept Missing Emission Factors attribute for an impact category, any entities lacking an emission factor for that category will be excluded from its specific calculation. This attribute can be enabled for each impact category individually. For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes.

Manage Inventory Scope

 

Manage Emission Factors

To calculate footprints for your desired Impact Categories, you must provide corresponding emission and/or impact factors. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management allows you to utilize pre-delivered emission factor data packages, or you can import your own data via the Manage Emission Factors app. This is a key area where the process expands significantly when moving beyond a single CO2e factor. The key considerations for managing emission factors for multiple impact categories are the following:

  • For each impact category you wish to assess, a specific impact factor is required. Therefore, when populating either the LCA or Simple Template, you must input a separate entry for each impact category. Although these factors might relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, they are differentiated by their distinct Impact Category ID.
  • Impact factors other than Climate Change (CLCH) must be added via Data Packages and cannot be manually inserted into the Emission Factor Periods in consuming apps such as Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities.
  • For importing emission factors, both the simple template (version 3) and the LCA template (version 5) in the Manage Emission Factors app have been enhanced to support multiple impact categories.

For details on maintaining emission factors data in the templates, see Emission Factors Data. Under Impact Categories, you find a table with all impact categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators.

Manage Emission Factors

After importing the relevant emission factors, you can move to the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app to map your imported products from your ERP system to the previously maintained emission factor datasets. Those must include data for the Climate Change impact category and can optionally include emission data for additional ones. The mapping can be done manually or AI-assisted â€“ with just one mapping, all available data for the impact categories is linked automatically. Clicking on a mapped dataset, provides you with an overview of all mapped content. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more information.

Manage Purchased Product Footprints

Similar to purchased products, the Manage Waste Footprints app enables you to manage the values used to calculate Climate Change and other environmental impacts resulting from the treatment of a specific type of waste within a defined period. Those can also be entered manually or mapped to maintained emission factor datasets. For more details, see Manage Waste Footprints.

Finally, Business Activities allow you to calculate environmental impacts based on form-based data collection. In the Manage Business Activities app, you can create those business activities and map the corresponding emission factor. For each business activity, you can determine which GHG scope the activity relates to. Find all details under Manage Business Activities.

 

Model Footprint Parameters

When calculating impacts for energy-related and transport activities, the Manage Locations app allows you to manage relevant locations. Ensure all locations pertinent to your chosen impact categories are added. See Manage Locations for more information.

The Model Energy Flows application is crucial for managing energy consumption and its associated impacts. When creating Energy Sources and their corresponding emission factor periods, you can now connect to emission factor datasets that include impact categories beyond just Climate Change. This means that the environmental impact of energy consumption, whether from electricity, fuel, or other sources, can now be assessed not only for its carbon footprint but also for its contribution to abiotic resource depletion or other selected impact categories, provided the relevant emission factors are assigned. While you can create a full energy flow model, including meter readings to allocate energy and emissions to locations, resources and manufactured products, you may also opt to create only the relevant Energy Sources required for your Corporate Carbon Footprint calculations. In both cases, the periodic consumption values, and if enabled the corresponding meter readings, are entered later in a GHG Data Form via the Record GHG Data app. For more information, see Model Energy Flows.

Manage Energy Source

For distributing environmental impacts from senders (e.g., Business Activities, Facilities, or Waste Types) to receivers (e.g., Facilities, Process Infrastructures, or Products), you can define Allocation Schemes and Allocation Rules in the Manage Allocations app. A sender is selected and linked to one or multiple receivers. The allocation ratio determines which portion of the senderâ€™s total impact (across all calculated impact categories) is allocated to each receiver. This ensures that the environmental impacts associated with, for example, a shared energy source are correctly attributed to the products or processes consuming that energy. Check Manage Allocations for all details.

 

Manage Periodic Data

To calculate environmental impacts related to purchased goods and services, business transactions need to be imported from your ERP system via the Import Business Transactions app. This includes data related to the movement of physical goods that are relevant for calculating product and corporate environmental impacts. Typical goods movement transactions that track the flow of products are: Opening Stock, Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Transfer, Goods Issue and Receipt from Production, and Internal Service Confirmation. Periodic data will be imported within the periodic boundaries defined in the Footprint Inventory Scope. These transactions form the basis for actual activity data that will be multiplied by the impact factors across all selected impact categories. Find more information under Import Business Transactions.

For capturing activity data for Energy Consumption, Meter Readings, Business Activities, and Waste Generated in Operations, the Manage GHG Data Collection and Record GHG Data applications offer a form-based data collection approach. You can enter activity values for each footprint inventory scope and period within these apps. While the apps are named with GHG, they now support the collection of activity data that will be linked to emission factors for all selected impact categories, not just greenhouse gases. For all details, see Manage GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

GHG Data Collection

 

Manage Footprint Calculations

Once all data is set up and provided in the preceding steps, the organizational environmental impact for the selected impact categories can be calculated. In the Calculate Footprints app, maintain the necessary data, such as the Footprint Inventory Scope, Calculation Variant, and Period. Before initiating the calculation, itâ€™s crucial to check for data completeness to ensure accurate results across all chosen impact categories. The calculation engine will then process all assigned impact factors against the activity data. For more information, see Calculate Footprints.

To view the detailed results per impact category, navigate to the Manage Footprint Results app or click Show Results directly within the Calculate Footprints app. You can then click on each calculated Footprint Item within the inventory to drill down into details. While the Sankey chart currently remains focused on Climate Change, the Footprint Information section now clearly displays the calculated impact categories per GHG scope (where applicable), along with the corresponding total footprint and footprint per unit for each impact category you selected. See Manage Footprint Results for details.

Manage Footprint Results

 

Analyze Footprints

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app provides a high-level summary of your impact calculation results. While the initial general overview and dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on the respective dashboards allows you to navigate to more detailed analyses. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information.

The Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organizationâ€™s environmental performance. While it may not yet offer specific multi-impact-category features distinct from the Climate Change balance, it serves as an overarching summary. For learning more about viewing organizational upstream and downstream emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application.

The Purchased Products analytics app now allows you to display calculated footprints by impact category via a filter option. This enables a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, providing a richer perspective than just CO2e. For more information, see Using the Purchased Products Application.

Purchased Product Footprints Analytics

Similarly, the Sold Products analytics app offers a filter option to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This is crucial for understanding the cradle-to-gate (or other defined boundary) impacts of products your organization sells, reported across various environmental indicators. Find more details under Using the Sold Products Application.

The Energy Consumers analytics app has been enhanced to allow you to choose and display the calculated footprints by impact category through a filter option. This provides granular insights into the environmental impacts (e.g., Climate Change, Resource Depletion) associated with energy consumption for specific entities within your organization. See Using the Energy Consumers Application to learn more.

Finally, also the Waste Generated in Operations analytics app now includes a filter option, enabling you to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This allows for a comprehensive assessment of the environmental burden from internal waste management across different environmental dimensions. Find more information here: Using the Waste Generated in Operations Application.

 

Communicate Footprints

For Communicating Footprints you can use different apps to perform the configurations required to make calculated footprints available to be consumed by other systems, for example, SAP Sustainability Control Tower and SAP Cloud ERP:

The Manage Footprint Communication app allows you to configure which footprint data be shared with other systems like SAP Sustainability Control Tower. Currently, it focuses on climate change results.

With the Publish Product Footprints (internal) app, you can publish calculated Product Carbon Footprints (PCFs) to connected SAP Cloud ERP systems for business process integration.

For supply chain collaboration, you can use the Publish Product Footprints (Carbon Data Exchange) app to publish PCFs externally to customers and partners leveraging the standardized PACT format.

 

Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub

Updates have also been made to existing APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to support the expanded impact category capabilities, now also supporting all categories in addition to Climate Change:

  • Item Footprints
  • Emission Factors

 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

To facilitate external reporting, especially for frameworks that require specific categorization of impacts, you can map your calculated impact category results to relevant reporting categories. The following figure illustrates how certain Climate Change sub-impact categories serve as building blocks to support different key reporting standards:

Impact Categories as Building Blocks for Key Reporting Standards

We plan to publish additional blog posts in the future to explain in detail how the mapping of calculated impact categories to the listed standardâ€™s reporting categories works â€“ stay tuned!

For general news on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, Iâ€™ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the productâ€™s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. Iâ€™m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: F4 Value Help for Step Condition in Flexible Workflow â€“ SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am working on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Public Edition) and trying to add F4 / Value Help for a custom parameter (Purchase Group) in a Flexible Workflow step condition.

Requirement

  • Add a custom step condition in Flexible Workflow

  • Enable F4 value help for the condition parameter

  • Values should come from a custom source (CDS / OData)

What I Have Tried So Far

  1. Implemented the Flexible Workflow BAdI

    • IF_SWF_FLEX_IFS_CONDITION_DEF

    • Defined custom condition and parameter successfully

    • The condition appears correctly in the workflow configuration

  2. Tried using a Custom CDS View (Value Help type)

    • Created CDS view with required fields

    • Enabled it as a Value Help

    • CDS activates successfully

  3. Attempted to connect CDS via OData

    • Created OData service for the CDS

    • Tried to consume this OData in the BAdI for value help

â— Issue:
At the final step, when trying to use the OData service inside the BAdI, the OData is not working / not accessible in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Because of this:

  • F4 help is not appearing in the workflow step condition

  • I am unable to bind CDS/OData as a value help source

My Questions

  1. Is it technically supported to provide F4 value help for Flexible Workflow step conditions in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

  2. Is there any approved way to consume CDS or OData for value help in this scenario?

  3. If this is a known limitation, is there any recommended workaround?

Any guidance or confirmation would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance.

Best Regards,
Jeet Kanabar

entry.title: Re: How to check authroization header in iFlow
entry.content:
As far as I know, you cannot leave iflow with FAILED status and respond with a specific HTTP status code & custom error message - it always returns 500.

In similar cases, what I do is leave the iflow with COMPLETED status (by ending with END MESSAGE) but set a custom status like 'BasicAuthUsed' for monitoring purposes to be able to find those runs.

Then you can set whatever you want by configuring the body with a custom error message & setting CamelHttpResponseCode = 401. Do it in Content Modifier or groovy. This will be returned to sender app.

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys
entry.content:
In this series:

  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys (this blog post)

API keys are required when called SAP Build Process Automation keys, but it can be confusing to know you need to provide, what different keys will return, and how to set it all up.

When do you need an API key?

Each environment lets you assign permissions to users for that environment. To do this, in the environment, click on Share.

Then you will be able to assign to a user specific authorizations. @Alex-Fortin (who is brilliant) has a wonderful blog about "shared" environments and assigning authorizations, including a table of what each authorization enables.

Different authorizations will allow you different API calls, but let's use the Workflow API as an example. If you have the Monitor authorization than you will be able to run the Workflow API for this environment.

To make it more complicated, you can also have the ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection (from the SAP BTP cockpit) and then you can run this API for any environment, without needing authorizations for any of the environments. 

And ll of this works WITHOUT ANY API KEY if you are authenticated using user token exchange. But if you are using client credentials and are authenticated simply as the service, then you need an API key. 

 

How to create an API key?

Go to the SAP Build Control Tower and click Others > API Keys. 

Then just create a new API key.

Then you set the following:

  • Name/Description
  • Scopes, that is, what authorizations assigned to the key. There is information on what each scope means 
  • Environments, that is, for which environments the key will work. You can specify one or more environments, or you can give the key access to all environments, including future ones. 

The scopes are explained in this documentation page. For reading workflow instances, you need trigger_read and environment_read scopes.

When you are finished, the key is displayed. You have one chance to copy it, and then you can no longer retrieve it from SAP Build.

Note that there is also a UI for creating API keys in each environment. The UI is the same except that that environment is automatically selected and you cannot select a different one.

 

What does API return based on the key?

If the API key is required, you must provide it as an HTTP header with the name api-key.

Note that the key used to be irpa-api-key, or something like that. I went crazy wondering why my API calls were not working, until something told me that the key name had apparently changed. ğŸ˜¾

The following is a summary of what happens given the example of calling the GET call of the Workflow API's workflow-instances, depending on:

  • How you authenticate
  • What role the user has (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether the user has the Monitor authorization for the given environment (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether an API key is sent that is valid and has the correct scopes for the given API
ProcessAutomationAdmin Role CollectionAPI KeyMonitor AuthorizationAuthenticationDoes API return values?
âœ…NANAUser Token Exchangeâœ…
âŒNAâœ…User Token Exchangeâœ…
âŒNAâŒUser Token Exchange âŒ
 NA âŒNA Client Credentials âŒ 
 NAâœ…NA Client Credentials âœ…

As an example, in this call:

  • I am authenticated using client credentials.
  • A URL parameter indicates to return only workflow instances from the salesgroup environment.
  • I supplied an API key for the salesgroup environment with trigger_read and environment_read  scopes  

And now I can see the running instances for that environment.

In upcoming blogs, we'll look at specific APIs, what they return/do and how to use them.

P.S.: Apologies for taking so long on this Part II ğŸ˜½

entry.title: Fast-Track Your Integrations To The Cloud Through Our New Expert-Guided Implementation Service
entry.content:
Fast-Track Your Integration Transformation To The Cloud Through Our New Expert-Guided Implementation service

Are you ready to migrate your critical integration scenarios to the cloud - in a secure and scalable way?

SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council is piloting a new expert guided implementation service (EGI) focused on helping customers starting to migrate their interfaces from SAP Process Integration / Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite. As a participant, youâ€™ll gain exclusive early access to content, influence the final offering with your feedback, and build hands-on experience before general availability. This isnâ€™t just another webinar - itâ€™s a practical, step-by-step experience where youâ€™ll migrate interfaces in your own environment, with guidance from an expert throughout.

This structured approach ensures you gain both theoretical knowledge and practical experience, helping you build confidence in using SAP solutions effectively. Since SAP Enterprise Support is included with every SAP cloud subscription, you can access this offering at no additional cost. 

After the completion of the 3-day remote workshop, you will have the knowledge of how to proceed to migrate their interfaces from SAP Process Integration / Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite.

â€‹The purpose of this EGI service is to support customers to begin their migration from SAP Process Integration (PI) / Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite.

â€‹Firstly, we discuss the value proposition of migrating to SAP Integration Suite, how to estimate the efforts involved in migrating using the Migration Assessment tool before migrating a simple interface to the SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool.

â€‹Finally, we prepare customers for developing integration scenarios using SAP Integration Suite in line with best practices using SAP Cloud Connector and the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Please see this teaser video for further information.

What Youâ€™ll Gain
 This service will equip you with the skills to leverage:

  • Migration Assessment tool to estimate the efforts involved in migrating interfaces to the cloud
  • Migration Tool to migrate a simple interface to the SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub to import and use standard integration scenarios

Why It Matters?
Customers should begin their migration from SAP Process Integration (PI) / Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite in advance of end-of-maintenance in 2027.

What Youâ€™ll Do?

  • Perform Migration Assessment to understand the effort involved in migrating to SAP Integration Suite.
  • Migrate a standard SAP PO Integrated Configuration Object (ICO) to an Integration Flow (Ready to Migrate).
  • Browse, select, and importing a standard integration package (e.g., Government interaction or Bank integration).
  • Gain practical experience with SAP expert support

Who Should Join?
The service is tailor-made for:

  • Integration consultants
  • Developers

Join the EGI service and gain first-hand experience with SAPâ€™s latest innovation in multi-model programming. Learn more and register for the service by contacting SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council through esac@sap.com.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

About the author: 

  • Robert Kelly is Architect Lead for BTP for SAP Enterprise Support. Based in Dublin, Ireland, Robert has been with SAP since 2005, holding various roles across the organization. Today, he focuses on helping businesses implement their digital transformation through SAP Enterprise Support offerings.

entry.title: Re: What can be done with the functional area in the glob...
entry.content:
Good day @seonjoong 

Thank you for your question

You can use the Activate functional area in Manage Global Hierarchies to build a hierarchy of functional areas for your reporting needs. It is not designed to assign G/L accounts. The Functional area is like a cost center or segment which the system derives from your master data or stored on your postings, then the functional area hierarchy is used to aggregate those postings in your reports. 

Here is a reference:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c56f622a2edf491b9f1b596b55587009/0e1df3837a7f4bf68c94083c3c9e1d4b.html?locale=en-US

Basically, saying that you cannot attach G/L accounts directly under functional areas in the hierarchy app. You should first ensure that your functional areas are maintained in the relevant master data before selecting Functional Areas as a dimension and choosing your global hierarchy.

As an example, you may consider the following scenario:

When you define functional areas:

  • 1000 Production
  • 2000 Sales
  • 2100 Domestic Sales
  • 2200 Export Sales

In Manage Global Hierarchies, you can build a hierarchy looking like this:

Operating Expenses

  • Production (1000)
  • Sales (2000)
    • DOM_SALES (2100)
    • EXP_SALES (2200)

In your Master Data:

Cost centers for production carry functional area 1000

Sales Cost Centers carry 2100 or 2200, etc.

 

  • OPERATING_EXPENSES
    • PRODUCTION (1000)
    • SALES (2000)
      • DOM_SALES (2100)
      • EXP_SALES (2200)

So, when your posting hit those cost centers, the functional area is derived. So, you select your functional area hierarchy and the system will aggregate all your postings e.g., your total Operating Expenses accordingly.

Have a look at the following references for more details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/c19642b1e9844fc8837c7a27bca79d0f.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f0d042517a434458b171ff5867b18445/c8de66216fde46cfb0e77199a2de504e.html?locale=en-US

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Integration of TM with Stock Transport Order â€“ Outbound Delivery Before Freight Order
entry.content:
Intro:
We are currently facing a challenge in the integration between SAP Transportation Management (TM) and the Stock Transport Order (STO) process. We would appreciate your advice or best practices on how to achieve the desired flow.

Current system behavior:

  1. Create UD Stock Transport Order (from one plant to another).
  2. Freight Units are created in the background.
  3. In the Transportation Cockpit, you must create a Freight Order first. Only then can you create the Outbound Delivery for the STO.

Desired process flow:

  1. Create UD Stock Transport Order (from one plant to another).
  2. Use the app â€œMy Purchase Orders Due for Deliveryâ€ to create the Outbound Delivery immediately.
  3. Go to the Transportation Cockpit and plan the transport based on the Outbound Delivery created in the previous step.

Question:
Is there any possibility to configure the system so that the Outbound Delivery can be created right after the STO, and then use that delivery/freight unit to create the Freight Order in TM?

Thank you in advance for your support and insights!

entry.title: Re: Different tax code behavior in F0859/FB60 â€“ Public vs...
entry.content:
Hello @BlasRosello4 

Thank you for your question.

Just to let you know, the attachments you uploaded are not visible.

The simple answer to your question is NO. The availability of multiple individual tax codes, which reflects the FB60 style behaviour is not available in public cloud. Therefore, you cannot activate this configuration. This means the public cloud uses one tax code for each line item, where each tax code can internally represent several tax components through the tax procedure and condition technique.

For Argentina requirements, the best practice is for you to design combined tax codes for each relevant combination and use tax determination conventions to keep them manageable for your users.

I am not aware of any published SAP Note or roadmap item that would change this and re-introduce the multiple tax codes in Tax tab concept for F0859 in the public cloud

Should you deem this as very important, you may log an improvement Request so SAP can evaluate multi-tax code entry for a future release. See link for details: 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ASSET_MANAGER/f0c0f7bd925243cbaaed88dc001fc213/5fa49e59c3a645ce8e75c8a27fe106be.html?locale=en-US

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Art of Possible: My Experience with SAP Ariba and WalkMe
entry.content:
A Digital Transformation Leader's Journey ğŸ’¼
    I've been working with Procurement transformation project using S4 , Oracle , SAP Ariba and WalkMe since 2023, and I want to share some practical insights from my experience. After SAP acquired WalkMe in September 2024, this combination has become even more important for procurement transformations. âœ¨
    Why I Started Looking at Digital Adoption Platforms ğŸ¤”
    Early in my career, I thought good system configuration and proper training were enough. But I was wrong. ğŸ˜… Users would complete training, get certificates, and then still struggle with the system. They forgot what they learned within weeks, created their own shortcuts, and kept calling the helpdesk.
    This is when I started exploring Digital Adoption Platforms like WalkMe. The idea was simple - instead of making users remember training, why not guide them exactly when they need help? ğŸ’¡
    My First WalkMe Implementation with SAP Ariba ğŸ¯
    In order to address System adoption challenge , we decided to use Walk-me for Ariba Guided buying transformation. We did a Business Value Assessment workshops with WalkMe's team. As part of those workshops we examinsed various workflows / Process flow and tried understanding user journey and when and how user are getting dropped and potential reasons behind it .
    They helped us understand where exactly users were getting stuck. It wasn't where we thought! For example, we assumed requisition creation was the problem, but users were actually struggling with basic catalog search and navigation. ğŸ”
    As outcome of this exercise we finalized 3 workflows for which we decided to develop walk-me content .
    How WalkMe Actually Reaches End Users ğŸ–¥ï¸
    Let me explain the technical setup because this confused me initially. ğŸ˜Š
    Getting WalkMe to Users' Computers âš™ï¸
    We worked with our IT team to install the WalkMe browser extension on all users' machines. This wasn't something users could download themselves â€“ with help of IT had to do a mass deployment. The good thing is WalkMe provides an All-In-One Installer. Our IT team could install it across with one installation file. This saved a lot of time and ensured everyone had the same setup. âœ…
    This installation was also done in phases where in region wise we installed to respective usebase.
    How Login and Access Works ğŸ”
    Here's something nice - WalkMe doesn't need separate login credentials. When users log into SAP Ariba Guided buying through our Single Sign-On (SSO), WalkMe automatically picks up those credentials. Users don't have to remember another password or do anything extra. ğŸ‘
    Once they're logged into Ariba Guided buying , WalkMe content appears automatically based on their role/persona and what they're doing in the system. From the user's side, it just feels like Ariba has become more helpful.
    What Users Actually See
    Users see a small Walk Me widget (usually in the corner) and helpful tips that pop up when needed. They don't need to do anything special - the help just appears at the right time. The extension runs quietly in the background, watching what users are doing and showing guidance when required.
    Building WalkMe Content: The Editor Tool & more ğŸ› ï¸
    Now, creating this content is a different story. As someone building the guidance, I use the WalkMe Editor.
    The Editor Setup ğŸ’»
    The WalkMe Editor is a desktop application that I install on my laptop. Along with it, there's an Editor Extension for the browser - this is different from what end users have. This confused me at first! ğŸ˜…
    The desktop app connects to my browser through this Editor Extension. This way, I can build content while looking at the actual Ariba screen side by side.
    When You Need Technical Skills ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’»
    For our receiving compliance solution (which I'll explain later), we had some write programming which involves jQuery and some HTML , CSS skills as that use case of bit complex .

    My Recommendation on Building Content
    In my experience, about 80% of WalkMe content can be built using drag-and-drop. The remaining 20% needs some degree of programming. Either have someone on your team who knows JavaScript, or pair your business users with a developer for the complex parts.In our case , Walk-me product experts helped us time to time .
    A Real Problem We Solved: Open Receiving Tasks ğŸ¯
    Let me share a specific challenge we faced during our Procurement transformation and how WalkMe helped us.
    The Problem âš ï¸
    We found that many users not completing receiving action in Ariba GB on time .This was causing supplier payment delay.
    Our Solution Using WalkMe ğŸ’¡
    We created a WalkMe ShoutOut (that's the popup notification) for users who had receiving tasks pending for more than one year. When they logged in, they saw a friendly but firm message: "You have pending receiving tasks that need attention."
    The message included a guided walkthrough that took them directly to the receiving screen and showed them how to complete these tasks step by step.
    We also added a process gate - if users tried to create a new requisition without completing their old receiving tasks, they'd see a reminder to complete them first. This wasn't about being strict; it was about maintaining data quality and helping users build better habits.

    AI Generated Mock-up for ideation.

    What Happened âœ…
    Within six weeks, the backlog of old receiving tasks was significantly reduced. More importantly, users started completing their receiving tasks on time. Its also reduced ticket volume for these issue with our support team.

    How its can help for S4 HANA transformations
    As now many organizations transitioning their ERP to latest version of S4 HANA , I belive walk-me can really good tool which expedites this . In normal scenario ,S4 HANA changes will have heavy dependency of ABAPer or SAP Technical resources but with walk-me such temporary changes can be managed in much shorter period .
    Eg.
    If for Particular Search help of Supplier we wanted hide some suppliers name or donâ€™t want to allow selection of supplier this changes will need ABAP programming .
    If such change is temporary in nature and after Supplier maintaince is complete , we wanted to revert change then it can be easily managed using Walk-me .

    Some common Use-cases possible in Ariba / S4 HANA
    â€¢ Smart walkthrough for Ariba Sourcing Event creation
    â€¢ Smart walkthrough for Ariba Non-Catalog PR
    â€¢ Temporarily hiding or blocking specific UI elements or buttons on Screens
    â€¢ Temporarily controlling user accesses during site migration
    â€¢ For Guided tour & as Companion offering help content is alongside respective Ariba Solution like Sourcing , SLP , GB etc.

    Challenges I've Faced ğŸ˜…
    Not everything has been smooth. Here are some real challenges:
    â€¢ Keeping Content Updated ğŸ”„: When Ariba releases updates, WalkMe content sometimes breaks. You need to regularly review and update it - this requires discipline.
    â€¢ Some Users Find It Annoying ğŸ˜’: Power users who know the system well sometimes find WalkMe guidance intrusive. I make most content dismissible, and check analytics to see what users are consistently ignoring.
    â€¢ Maintenance Takes Effort âš™ï¸: Creating WalkMe content is relatively easy, but keeping it current as business processes change needs proper ownership and governance.
    â€¢ Multi-System Complexity ğŸ”—: In companies using both SAP and non-SAP systems, ensuring consistent WalkMe experience across all systems needs careful planning.
    Results I've Seen ğŸ“ˆ
    Every organization is different, but here are some consistent patterns:
    â€¢ Training time for new users has reduced noticeably â±ï¸
    â€¢ Helpdesk gets fewer "how do I" questions ğŸ“
    â€¢ Data quality in requisitions and purchase orders has improved âœ…
    â€¢ Business process changes / critical announcements can be communicated faster through Walk-Me than waiting for formal training sessions or meetings ğŸš€
    â€¢ Change management teams feel more empowered to help users quickly ğŸ’ª
    Practical Tips for Digital Transformation Leaders ğŸ’¡
    If you're considering WalkMe for SAP Ariba or S4HANA, here's my advice:
    â€¢ Do Proper Assessment ğŸ”: Talk to your users and check analytics to understand where they actually struggle, not where you think they struggle.
    â€¢ Involve Real Users Early ğŸ‘¥: Test your WalkMe content with actual end users before rolling it out. Their feedback can be surprising but very valuable.
    â€¢ Build in Small Pieces ğŸ§©: Create reusable content blocks. A tooltip used in multiple places is better than creating separate content everywhere.
    â€¢ Plan for Ownership ğŸ“‹: Decide who will maintain WalkMe content, how often it gets reviewed, and how updates are managed. This isn't exciting work but it's critical.
    â€¢ Measure Business Impact ğŸ“Š: Don't just look at WalkMe analytics. Check if requisition completion rates improved, if policy compliance increased, if support tickets reduced.
    â€¢ Start Small ğŸŒ±: Begin with one critical process or one user group or region. Prove the value, then expand.
    Final Thoughts ğŸ’­
    Working with WalkMe and SAP Ariba /S4 HANA has taught me that technology transformation is really about people. The best procurement system won't deliver value if users can't or won't use it properly.
    WalkMe isn't a magic solution. ğŸª„ It's a useful tool that, when implemented thoughtfully and maintained regularly, can significantly improve how users work with SAP Ariba.
    The art of the possible isn't about fancy technology - it's about making technology work better for people who use it every day. â¤ï¸

    The Way forward with Walk-me + SAP Joule
    The road ahead looks promising as WalkMe and SAP Joule continue to merge into a unified, intelligent experience layer. The Sapphire 2025 demo was just a preview of whatâ€™s coming. WalkMeâ€™s realâ€‘time guidance and automation will increasingly amplify Jouleâ€™s generative AI capabilities â€” creating a powerful model where Joule provides the intelligence, and WalkMe drives the execution.
    These are my personal observations from my experience in digital transformation. Results may vary based on your organization's specific situation.

entry.title: Re: The technical team is unable to utilize CDS views for...
entry.content:
Good day @Saisaini 

Thank you for your question

The reason why your technical team is not able to utilize both I_ProcessOrderItemTP and I_PROCESSORDERCOMPONENTTP CDS views for analytical queries or custom report is, although they are visible in the Customer Data Browser, they have not been released for key-user reporting in public cloud.

So, for your custom reports the best option is to use CDS views that are released for manufacturing, for example the I_ManufactruingOrderItem you mentioned plus other released component views. If you require, you can join them together in a Custom CDS View to appropriate the data you currently see in the TP view.

Should any field exist only in the TP view and no released CDS exposes them, I am not aware of any supported way to report on them with key-user tools today. I suggest you either open an incident or raise a Customer Influence request to SAP.

 

 

Best regards

Chris
