entry.title: AI-Driven Enterprise Data Architecture for Predictive Supply Chain Optimization in SAP Landscapes
entry.content:
Abstract :   

AI-driven supply chain optimization has emerged as a critical capability for enterprises facing demand volatility, supplier uncertainty, and operational complexity. However, many initiatives fail to deliver sustainable value due to fragmented data foundations and poorly aligned architectures. This article presents a structured enterprise data architecture that enables scalable, explainable, and production-ready AI/ML solutions for supply chain optimization. By integrating SAP S/4HANA, SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP BTP, the proposed framework supports predictive use cases such as demand forecasting, goods receipt delay prediction, and inventory optimization. The study emphasizes architecture-first design, feature engineering, and operational integration over algorithmic experimentation alone. Methodologies, workflows, equations, and comparative insights are provided to guide practitioners in transitioning from reactive reporting to predictive and prescriptive decision-making. The article aims to bridge the gap between enterprise data engineering and applied machine learning within SAP landscapes.

Introduction

Global supply chains are increasingly exposed to disruptions driven by market volatility, geopolitical risks, and evolving customer expectations. Traditional supply chain systems rely heavily on descriptive reporting and rule-based planning, which limits their ability to anticipate future risks and opportunities. As a result, enterprises are turning to artificial intelligence and machine learning to improve forecasting accuracy, inventory resilience, and operational responsiveness.

Despite growing interest, many AI initiatives struggle due to siloed data, inconsistent semantics, and lack of integration with business processes. This highlights the importance of enterprise data architecture as the foundation for successful AI adoption. Within SAP ecosystems, rich transactional data already exists, but it must be curated, governed, and structured for predictive consumption. This article introduces a practical architecture and workflow that enables AI-driven supply chain optimization by aligning data engineering, analytics, and operational execution within SAP platforms.

Purpose & Scope :

The purpose of this article is to define a practical and reusable enterprise data architecture for AI/ML-driven supply chain optimization in SAP environments. The scope includes data ingestion, harmonization, feature engineering, model lifecycle management, and business consumption of predictions. Rather than focusing on a single algorithm or tool, the article emphasizes architectural design principles that ensure scalability, governance, and explainability.

The scope covers core supply chain use cases such as demand forecasting, goods receipt delay prediction, and inventory optimization. It also addresses integration with SAP Analytics Cloud for planning and SAP BTP for operational workflows. Out-of-scope areas include low-level algorithm tuning and vendor-specific benchmarking. The goal is to provide architects, data engineers, and analytics practitioners with a structured blueprint that can be adapted across industries and SAP landscapes.

Background : 

Supply chain analytics has traditionally focused on historical reporting and KPI tracking. While useful, these approaches are inherently reactive. Advances in machine learning enable predictive modeling, but success depends on data quality, feature consistency, and system integration. SAP ecosystems provide a strong transactional backbone, yet AI adoption requires rethinking how data is modeled, governed, and operationalized. Enterprise data architecture plays a critical role in transforming raw transactional data into predictive intelligence. 

Category Identification : 

This work falls under the categories of Enterprise Data Architecture, AI/ML-Driven Analytics, and Supply Chain Optimization. From a research perspective, it aligns with applied industrial analytics and decision support systems. From a practitioner perspective, it addresses architecture, governance, and operational integration within SAP platforms. The article bridges research-oriented machine learning concepts with enterprise-grade system design. 

Research Background : 

Existing research on supply chain optimization highlights the effectiveness of machine learning in demand forecasting, lead-time prediction, and inventory management. However, much of the literature assumes clean, centralized datasets and overlooks enterprise integration challenges. Practitioner studies reveal that architecture misalignment, feature inconsistency, and lack of monitoring are primary causes of AI failure in production. This work builds on prior research by explicitly embedding ML workflows within enterprise SAP architectures, emphasizing governance, explainability, and lifecycle management as first-class concerns.

Novel Contribution : 

The novel contribution of this article lies in its architecture-centric framing of AI-driven supply chain optimization. Rather than proposing a new algorithm, it introduces a structured enterprise architecture that operationalizes ML models within SAP ecosystems. The integration of feature engineering, MLOps, and business consumption into a single workflow differentiates this work from isolated analytical studies.

Methodology & Workflow :

 

Architectural Workflow

The methodology follows a layered enterprise architecture:

Layer

Components

Function

Source

SAP S/4HANA, External Systems

Transactional data

Data Foundation

SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA

Harmonization & semantics

Feature Layer

HANA Views, Python

Feature engineering

ML Layer

HANA PAL, Python ML

Training & inference

Consumption

SAC, Fiori, APIs

Decision support

Feature Engineering

Key predictive features include:

Feature Type

Examples

Temporal

Month, seasonality index

Vendor

Reliability score, failure rate

Logistics

Transit variance, route delay

Inventory

Stock turnover, safety stock

 Core Equations

Demand Forecasting (Regression):

Delay Probability (Classification):

Inventory Safety Stock:

Model Lifecycle

Models are trained on historical data, validated using back-testing, deployed via SAP BTP APIs, and monitored for drift and accuracy degradation. Governance ensures role-based access and auditability.

Comparative Insight

Compared to traditional rule-based planning, the proposed architecture enables proactive decision-making. Unlike isolated ML implementations, this framework ensures consistency, reuse, and operational stability. Centralized feature engineering and governed data models significantly improve prediction reliability while reducing duplication across teams.

Potential Applications

Applications include predictive demand planning, supplier risk scoring, dynamic inventory optimization, and logistics delay mitigation. The architecture is adaptable across manufacturing, retail, and logistics industries.

Broader Implications

Beyond supply chain optimization, this architecture demonstrates how enterprise data foundations enable trustworthy AI adoption. It supports explainability, regulatory compliance, and organizational trust in AI-driven decisions.

Full References

References include foundational works on supply chain analytics, enterprise data architecture, and applied machine learning, along with SAP documentation on Datasphere, HANA PAL, and Analytics Cloud. These sources collectively inform the architectural and methodological choices presented.

Ethics + Review Framework

Ethical considerations include data privacy, bias mitigation, and transparency of predictions. Models are reviewed using explainability metrics, accuracy thresholds, and periodic audits. A human-in-the-loop framework ensures AI augments, rather than replaces, expert decision-making.

entry.title: 03 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 - Customer Readiness and ownership
entry.content:
This blog walks through the key areas customers should focus on, along with the ownership plan for the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by turning the focus to customer readiness.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

Customer readiness is essential to the success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. The following are key items customers should plan for as part of Phase 0.

  1. Execution ownership
  2. Project Business Outcome and Goals
  3. Enterprise Architectural Strategy and Infrastructure Readiness
  4. Business and HR Ownership
  5. Data Migration Workstream ownership
  6. Technical Integration Workstream
  7. Testing Strategy and execution
  8.  Training and Sustainment
  9.  Resource Allocation and Planning

1. Ownership of the project execution.

This is a critical decision for customers: should the system integrator (SI) lead the implementation, or should the customer take the lead? Customer-led projects tend to offer greater transparency at every stage, making it easier to identify risks early and address them effectively. That said, customers must realistically assess whether they have the internal resources and capabilities to manage the project in this way.

What is a customer lead project?

Each workstream within the project has an assigned owner accountable for execution, supported by the system integrator (SI). The customer Business and HR teams lead the initiative, while the SI contributes SuccessFactors SMEs and consultants to deliver the required work.

2) Define and Align Project Business Outcomes and Goals

 Defining project business outcomes and effectively communicating them to the project team are critical steps. As part of this process,

  • Define HR Strategy and Goals: Clearly articulate the specific HR challenges to be addressed and set measurable objectives (e.g., reduce time-to-hire, increase employee engagement, automate manual tasks, adopt SAP Business AI, integrate better with ERP systems, provide better reporting, etc) and make sure that SI is aligned.
  • Establish Project Governance: Define the project team structure, decision-making processes, roles, and responsibilities (for both the customer and the implementation partner/SI).
  • Implementation Approach: Determine the deployment strategy, including which modules will be implemented
  • Current State Analysis & Process Mapping: Documenting existing HR processes ("As-Is") to understand current pain points and identify simplification opportunities.
  • Future State Vision: Begin defining the "To-Be" processes, aligning them with SAP SuccessFactors HCM leading practices and the "clean core" mindset.

3. Enterprise Architecture Stagey and Infrastructure Readiness  

 HR data is used by many internal and external applications, so implementing SAP SuccessFactors HCM requires thinking beyond just HR. From an enterprise architecture and infrastructure perspective, customers should involve enterprise and solution architects to assess the impact on the technology stack, help align the project with the overall technology architecture, and ensure that architecture, design, and adoption stay aligned with the broader strategy.

  • Define Clean Core guidelines  â€“Ensure the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation follows the clean core strategy and standardized (Fit-to-Standard approach), and focus on reducing technical debt and manual work.

         Check the blog below for clean core guidelines for SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/02-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-clean-core-guidelines/ba-p/14289052

  • SAP BTP as the Innovation Layer: SAP Integration Suite is usually used as the middleware layer, and SAP BTP is leveraged for building or enhancing capabilities. Make sure you have a clear strategy in place. If youâ€™re already using SAP BTP for SAP S/4HANA or other SAP solutions, ensure that your SuccessFactors implementation follows the same guidelines and aligns with your overall strategy.
  • Data & Analytics: Utilize SAP BDC  on BTP for centralized, governed data insights and build a data lake platform. If you already have a Data platform like Snowflake, Databricks, KAFKA, etc. Have a staged approach to data sync and reporting.
  • SAP Business AI: Aligned with the organizationâ€™s AI adoption strategy, formulate a plan for implementing SAP Business AI for HCM. While SAP has prebuilt agentic use cases, any development of additional Joule skills and agents should follow a well-defined strategy to identify business cases and design effective automation solutions. 
  • Identity management and Security: Implement SAP Cloud Identity Services for central access governance across all cloud components.
  • Infrastructure Assessment: Ensure the necessary IT infrastructure and validation of new tools if they meet organization standards, Security( SAP IAS, SAP BTP/SF SLAs, SAP Cloud connector, Edge Integration Cell etc.)                                                          

4. Business and HR Ownership, Module Leads

Clear lines of accountability are essential to ensure the implementation meets business requirements and is adopted effectively. A designated workstream (module) lead should be identified for each SAP SuccessFactors HCM module, including Integration, Testing, and Data Migration. Each module lead will act as the primary point of contact for their assigned scope.

  • Module leads play a critical role and work closely with SI leads to conduct Fit-to-Standard workshops.
  • Validate solution design and manage module configuration, master data readiness, and security and authorizations within the module.
  • Ensure alignment between the module configuration and the approved Global Process Design (GPO sign-off).
  • Lead Unit Testing and support business users during Integration Testing (IT) and User Acceptance Testing (UAT).
  • Select workstream leads strategically, ensuring their current role and expertise are appropriate to lead the workstream.

 

Responsibility Area

Owner

Key Activities

Business/HR Ownership

Senior Business/HR Sponsors & Process Owners

Ultimate accountability for successful adoption, realization of benefits, and validating the final solution design.

Current Business Process Review (AS-IS)

Process Owners & Module Leads

Detailed documentation and analysis of existing processes to identify pain points, regulatory constraints, and non-value-add steps.

Design Ownership (TO-BE)

Global Process Owners (GPOs) & Solution Architects

Defines the standardized, future-state processes. Approves all deviations from standard  functionality (Fit-Gap analysis).

Data Ownership

Data Lead & Functional Owners

Responsible for data quality, migration mapping, cleaning, validation of data, and ongoing data governance in the new system.

 5. Data Migration Workstream ownership 

Data migration is a critical activity requiring substantial effort and resources. The customer, having comprehensive knowledge of existing data, should take the lead in the data workstream, overseeing all migration activities in coordination with the SI. 

  • Collaborate with SI resources to develop a comprehensive Data Migration Strategy.
  • Oversee and coordinate data migration activities, encompassing extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Establish data quality standards and implement data cleansing processes in legacy systems before migration.
  • Identify all relevant data sources.
  • Define a robust data validation strategy to ensure integrity.
  • Develop and implement a data scrambling strategy to safeguard sensitive information.

6. Technical Integration Workstream 

Technical integration demands substantial effort. While the SI may develop the integrations, the customer is responsible for providing requirements, coordinating with application owners to assess impacts, and supporting interface testing, among other related tasks. 

  • Develop a current state integration inventory, review it with the SI team, and produce a final draft of integrations required for the future state.
  • Establish integration patterns aligned with the anticipated future scope.
  • Define a comprehensive integration strategy.
  • Validate SAP Integration Suite and SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center tools to ensure consistency with the overall integration strategy.
  • Identify legacy systems to be replaced and those to be retained.
  • Determine and implement a communication plan with vendors.
  • Prepare detailed integration requirement documents for all integrations in scope.
  • Design the future state technical landscape in collaboration with the SI team.                                                                                              

7. Testing Strategy and execution

Develop a well-defined testing strategy and designate accountability. Comprehensive testing is essential to mitigate post-go-live disruptions and enhance overall satisfaction with the SAP SuccessFactors HCM solution.

  • Define Ownership of Testing strategy and execution.
  • Resource availability to create test scenarios for all modules and integrations.
  • Tools to use for Testing( Automation Testing, Manual Testing)
  • Define clear target goals for each test cycle (SIT,UAT, End Testing, Payroll Parallel)
  • Even though using Automation Tools reduces manual testing efforts, manual testing is still required to validate some of the process that requires a good number of resources from the business / Testing, and Integration team.
  • Map all your test scenarios to business requirements, processes etc. Each Test scenario must represent a traceable requirement.

8. Training and Sustainability Strategy:

The success of an SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation depends heavily on user adoption and the systemâ€™s continued relevance. Ensure that all usersâ€”including employees, managers, HR, and system administratorsâ€”are proficient with the platform, and that the system remains optimized and aligned with evolving business needs well beyond the initial go-live..

  • Make sure module leads and business/HR teams get training at the start of the projectâ€”it will help them validate the solution design and understand future processes.
  • SAP Learning Hub is a great resource for the team to build their knowledge.
  • Get hands-on access to the SuccessFactors system and get comfortable using it.
  • Use WalkMe to help guide users and support learning in the system.                                                                                                 

9. Resource Allocation and Planning:

Precise forecasting of customer resource availability and required time commitment is essential to project success. At the conclusion of Phase 0, the customer must have a comprehensive resource plan and allocation details to ensure appropriate staffing during the implementation phase.

 

Project Role

Allocation

Project Manager

 

Module Leads

 

Technical Leads

 

Data Migration Team

 

Testing Team

 

Business Analysts

 

Technical Resources

 

OCM Team

 

PS: The blog post content is based solely on my experience leading multiple SAP Global rollouts.

entry.title: SAP Fiori tools 2601 update â€“ Mobile Device Preview, Building Blocks, and AI-Driven Productivity
entry.content:
With the latest SAP Fiori tools update 2601, we continue our focus on improving developer productivity, openness, and real-world usability. This release brings meaningful enhancements across previewing applications, managing system connections, building SAP Fiori elementsâ€“based UIs, and accelerating development with AI-powered tooling. At the same time, weâ€™ve continued to refine the fundamentals in security, modelling, and extensibility.

Preview SAP Fiori Apps on Real Mobile Devices

When developing SAP Fiori applications, simulating a mobile experience in a desktop browser often isnâ€™t enough to fully validate real-world behavior. Touch interactions, performance characteristics, and device-specific rendering can differ noticeably on physical phones and tablets.

To address this, SAP Fiori tools now supports previewing applications directly on real mobile devices when using @sap/ux-ui5-tooling version 1.19.1 or higher. By creating a new run configuration and enabling Remote Access, developers can expose the local preview. When the run configuration is started, the terminal provides connection details, including a URL and a QR code, which can be opened directly on a phone or tablet to access the running app.

This makes it significantly easier to validate layouts, navigation, and interactions exactly as end users will experience them without leaving the development environment.

Showcase for previewing a SAP Fiori elements app on iPhone

A New Connection Manager for SAP Systems in VS Code

Managing connections to remote SAP systems is a foundational task when working with SAP Fiori tools. With this release, we introduce the Connection Manager for SAP Systems as a dedicated Visual Studio Code extension. This new extension succeeds the previously integrated saved systems panel from the Application Modeler and provides a focused, extensible solution for handling system connections in Visual Studio Code.

The Connection Manager allows developers to create, store, test, and edit connection information that can be reused by the SAP Fiori generator as well as by preview features in SAP Fiori tools. Storing passwords is optional, and if stored, they are protected by the security policies of your operating system's credential manager.

By making this capability standalone and open source, it is now accessible to other extensions such as the Service Catalog extension, and open for community contributions.

Connection Manager

Expanded Support for SAP Fiori Elements Building Blocks

SAP Fiori tools continues to enhance the support for the building blocks which shape the framework of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 and its flexibility you can use. It makes it easier to create and adapt applications using a structured, metadata-driven approach while keeping flexibility in design. In this update, the Page Editor gains additional capabilities that improve developer convenience when working with custom pages and sections.

Developers can now add more building block types to their apps with the Page Editor, including rich text editors within custom sections, custom columns for table building blocks, and the page building block itself. Managing custom pages is also more intuitive, as building blocks can now be deleted directly from the editor. To support experimentation and iteration, undo and redo actions are now available when working on custom pages.

Together, these enhancements reduce friction when adapting applications and allow developers to work more confidently and efficiently with SAP Fiori elementsâ€“based UIs.

Rich Text Editor building block support in Page Editor

Enhancements Across the AI-Toolchain

AI capabilities continue to evolve across SAP Fiori tools, with a strong focus on usability and enabling deeper end-to-end changes from within the tooling.

The Project Accelerator can now be launched directly from the SAP Fiori generator, streamlining the initial project creation flow. The previously required staging step has been removed, allowing new projects to be created directly in the selected workspace folder. For projects created using the Project Accelerator, the Application Modeler now offers advanced editing capabilities, such as creating new fields and properties end-to-end, updating the data model, exposing the service, and consuming the changes in the UI in one coherent flow.

AI support has also been extended to mock data generation. Developers can generate realistic mock data using AI directly in the Application Modeler, and this capability is available for all applications whenever the Project Accelerator is enabled.

In parallel, the MCP server for SAP Fiori continues to expand. The server now exposes @sap-ux/create commands as CLI functionality, enabling reliable execution in MCP-supported workflows. App generation has been extended to support CAP Java projects, and a new â€œsearch_docsâ€ tool allows the LLM (Large Language Model) to query SAP Fiori elements documentation, annotations, SAP Fiori tools documentation, and SAP Fiori Development Portal resources to quickly find relevant guidance and code snippets.

Continuous Improvements and Refinements

Beyond the headline features, this release includes a range of continuous improvements that strengthen the overall development experience. Newly created CAP applications now use NPM workspaces by default, establishing best practices out of the box and enabling the use of @sap/ux-ui5-tooling middlewares when previewing CAP-based applications.

The Application Modeler has been enhanced with additional SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 features, including support for hidden draft mode, improved configuration options for table create dialogs, and create support for custom fields in form sections. These additions give developers more control over application behavior without leaving the modeling environment.

Security and user management have also been strengthened. The ABAP Cloud connection type in the Connection Manager has been consolidated around re-entrance ticket authentication, moving away from service keyâ€“based authentication. This eliminates long-lived shared credentials and ties system access directly to the signed-in user, improving both security and maintainability.

Looking Ahead

We are already working on the next set of enhancements for SAP Fiori tools. Planned improvements include a rework and enhancement of OPA5 test generation, with added support for value help services and mock data generation. Project validation will be extended with new domain-specific ESLint rule sets, visualized directly in the Application Modeler, alongside support for ESLint 9.

Support for additional SAP Fiori elements building blocks, such as form and field, is also on the roadmap. On the AI side, we continue to improve the robustness and usefulness of responses from the MCP server, while the Project Accelerator will be extended to support RAP service creation.

As always, we look forward to your feedback and contributions as we continue to evolve SAP Fiori tools together with the community.

entry.title: Learning Circle Experience: Change Management in SAP-Projekten â€“ Retrospektive und Erkenntnisse
entry.content:
Nach zwÃ¶lf Wochen Peer-Learning zu Organizational Change Management (OCM) in SAP-Projekten trafen sich die Teilnehmenden am 16. Dezember 2025 zur finalen Retrospektive. Das Format basiert auf selbstorganisierten Lernzirkeln, die einen strukturierten Leitfaden (LernOS Leitfaden Change Management) als Grundlage nutzten und lebt vor allem vom Austausch der Teilnehmenden.

Check-In: Woher kommt ihr?

Die Teilnehmenden begrÃ¼ÃŸten sich und teilten ihre Standorte mit, darunter Mannheim, Bern, Karlsruhe, Mainz, Hamburg, EckernfÃ¶rde, Oy-Mittelberg, Furtwangen, Kreuzlingen, Norderstedt und Rotenberg. Wir vom Orga-Team waren auf Einladung von Simon DÃ¼ckert in NÃ¼rnberg in der Cogneon Akademie.

Inhaltliche und methodische Lern-Erfahrungen â€“ Reflektion der Befragung

Im Vorfeld haben 30 Teilnehmende eine Umfrage beantwortet, die ich hier kurz zusammen fasse.

Die meisten Teilnehmenden der Retrospektive und der Umfrage haben die LeitfÃ¤den und Lerngruppen bis zum Ende durchgefÃ¼hrt. Aus dem Bauch heraus wÃ¼rde ich sagen, daÃŸ ca. die HÃ¤lfte der initial Angemeldeten und somit so ca. 100 -120 Personen in Lernzirkeln gelernt haben.

Was waren die Erfahrungen in den Lernzirkeln?

Wertvoller Austausch und Input

Die Teilnehmenden bewerteten den Peer-Austausch als zentralen Mehrwert. Viele Best Practices wurden geteilt, der Erfahrungsaustausch erwies sich als wertvoll. Die DiversitÃ¤t der Perspektiven und unterschiedliche Standpunkte zu Projekten wurden als sehr bereichernd empfunden.

Wir sehen das oft in Lernzirkeln: Der Leitfaden gibt die Struktur und etwas Input - das eigentliche Lernen erfolgt durch die Erfahrung & Reflektion der Gruppenteilnehmenden.

Positive Gruppendynamik

Die gemischten Vorkenntnisse der Gruppenmitglieder erwiesen sich als StÃ¤rke. Teilnehmende mit unterschiedlichem Change-Management-Wissensstand trafen sich wÃ¶chentlich. Die verschiedenen Herausforderungen und Themen, mit denen andere konfrontiert waren, boten interessante Einblicke. Der Mix an Know-how und Erfahrung machte die Treffen kurzweilig und spannend.

Positive Grundstimmung

Das Feedback war Ã¼berwiegend positiv â€“ die Teilnehmenden beschrieben die Erfahrung als bereichernd, inspirierend und herausfordernd, insbesondere wenn es darum ging, die Lernzeit mit der Arbeit zu vereinbaren. Die Initiative wurde als absolut positiv bewertet. Einige wÃ¼rden das Format "immer wieder gerne" nutzen.

Lernformat und Organisation

Die wÃ¶chentlichen Austauschtreffen funktionierten gut. Das Konzept des Lernens in Lerngruppen erwies sich als hilfreich. Der Gruppendruck half, das Ziel nicht aus den Augen zu verlieren. Die Organisation durch SAP wurde als gut strukturiert wahrgenommen.

Content und Methodik

Der angebotene Leitfaden erwies sich als sinnvoll. Die Kombination aus Selbststudium, Aufgaben verknÃ¼pft mit Projekterfahrung und Peer-Austausch funktionierte bei Ã¼berschaubarem Zeitaufwand.

Fachliche Change-Management-Erkenntnisse

Die Teilnehmenden gewannen unterschiedliche inhaltliche Einsichten â€“ anbei ein Auswahl:

  • Verschiedene grundsÃ¤tzliche Change-AnsÃ¤tze kamen zur Anwendung
  • Change Management gelingt am besten, wenn Menschen frÃ¼hzeitig einbezogen, transparent informiert, empathisch begleitet und strukturiert durch den VerÃ¤nderungsprozess gefÃ¼hrt werden
  • Das Commitment des Managements muss vorhanden sein und auf Ernsthaftigkeit geprÃ¼ft werden
  • Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist ein wichtiges Drehkreuz, weil damit die Beteiligten entsprechend eingebunden werden
  • Offene Kommunikation und aktives ZuhÃ¶ren sind zentral, um VerÃ¤nderungen gemeinsam zu verstehen und erfolgreich umzusetzen
  • Bedeutung des Change Managements fÃ¼r organisationale Ã„nderungen wurde vertieft, neue Aspekte kennengelernt

Herausforderungen beim Lernen in Lernzirkeln

Zeitliche Herausforderungen

Der Alltag mit seinen Herausforderungen kam oft in die Quere. Es erwies sich als schwierig, in einer Gruppe zu lernen, wenn viele andere PrioritÃ¤ten dazwischenkommen. Die Teilnehmenden reflektierten: "Besser kurz als gar nicht" und "Zeit, die mit Lernen verbracht wird, ist gut investierte Zeit".

AbhÃ¤ngigkeit vom Engagement

Das Format funktioniert nur mit zuverlÃ¤ssigen, engagierten Teilnehmenden. Fehlendes Commitment anderer wurde als Problem genannt. Es braucht WissenstrÃ¤ger in der Gruppe.

Kritische Stimmen

Einzelne Teilnehmende fanden das Format nicht bereichernd. FÃ¼r manche war und ist es wohl nicht das richtige Format. Auch fanden 2 Teilnehmenden die Inhalte oberflÃ¤chlich â€“ wobei der Leitfaden eigentlich fÃ¼r Beginner und Grundlagen gedacht ist.

Feedback aus einigen Lerngruppen

Innovative Praxis: KI-gestÃ¼tzte Change-Workshops und KI Begleitung

Simon DÃ¼ckert lernte mit einem KI-Buddy alleine, da er fÃ¼r eine Lerngruppe keine Zeit hatte. Er berichtete von einem experimentellen Ansatz, bei dem er KI-Tools fÃ¼r Change-Management-Workshops und zur Konzeptgestaltung einsetzt. Die Methode kombiniert Change-Management-Literatur sowie den Leitfaden zusammen mit kundenspezifischen Dokumenten und nutzt Claude sowie Open WebUI. Das System generiert vollstÃ¤ndige Konzeptdokumente inklusive FahrplÃ¤nen fÃ¼r zwÃ¶lf Monate, KommunikationsplÃ¤nen mit Gantt-Diagrammen und personalisierten Lernpfaden.

Die Visualisierung erfolgt Ã¼ber das Mermaid-Format fÃ¼r Mindmaps und Gantt-Diagramme. Der entscheidende Vorteil: Am Ende des Workshops liegt ein konkretes Arbeitsdokument vor, nicht erst nach einer Woche Nachbereitung. Somit kann er sehr schnell und effizient Change-Management Konzepte erstellen. Geplant sind Chatbots, die den erweiterten Change-Kontext kennen und personalisierte Inhalte bereitstellen kÃ¶nnen.

Es gibt Ã¼brigens einen lernOS KI Leitfaden: https://ai.lernos.org. Er ist derzeit jedoch nicht voll up-to-date â€“ Themen wie Reasoning Modelle, Agenten fehlen noch.

Erfahrungen aus der Gruppe "Changemakers"

Adelheid, die auch in NÃ¼rnberg zu Gast war, berichtete von ihrer Gruppe mit Ann-Kristin BÃ¼rke, Laura Schladitz, Tanita Bahr und Stefan Vossen. Die Dynamik basierte auf gegenseitiger UnterstÃ¼tzung: Laura stellte beispielsweise ein Hochschulangebot vor, bei dem Change-Prozesse vor Projektstart simuliert werden. Stefan Vossen teilte Praxisbeispiele zu SAP Enable Now, wÃ¤hrend Tanita Bahr bzgl. einem Bosch-Rollout ihre aktuellen Herausforderungen einbrachte und direktes Feedback erhielt.

Der Austausch funktionierte als wechselseitiges Lernen â€“ jeder brachte seine Expertise ein, niemand war nur Lehrender oder nur Lernender. Der Leitfaden diente als Struktur, die eigentliche Lernerfahrung entstand durch den Dialog.

Erfahrungen aus der Gruppe "Freitags-Holzhacker"

Diese Gruppe traf sich regelmÃ¤ÃŸig freitags von 8 bis 9 Uhr. Die Teilnehmenden lasen vorab die Materialien und nutzten die gemeinsame Zeit fÃ¼r Praxisaustausch.

Michael Kallus, als IT Journalist ohne direkten SAP-Projektbezug, gewann tiefe Einblicke in IT-Transformationen. Besonders beeindruckte ihn die Stakeholder-Analyse als Ausdruck von WertschÃ¤tzung â€“ keine alleinige Excel-Liste, sondern ein Werkzeug, um Menschen entsprechend ihrer Interessen einzubinden. Auch die Vorbereitung eines Meetings mit Dashboard demonstrierte ihm den Wert professioneller Moderation.

Interesse an weiteren Peer-Learning AktivitÃ¤ten

Die Umfrage unter 30 Personen zeigte: 27 mÃ¶chten weitere Peer-Learning-AktivitÃ¤ten durchfÃ¼hren. Die Themenvielfalt reicht von SAP Activate, Key User Management, WalkMe und Sustainability Ã¼ber KI-Anwendungen bis zu Change Management Vertiefungen in Change Impact Analysis und Leadership im OCM-Kontext. Dabei dominierten die SAP Themen stark, gefolgt von Vertiefung in Change Management Themen. Anbei eine Grafik dazu:

Feedback zum Leitfaden und der DurchfÃ¼hrung.

Auf die Frage, ob Interesse an Ask-me-Anything Sessions wÃ¶chtentlich bestanden hÃ¤tte fÃ¼r mehr Guidance war die RÃ¼ckmeldung geteilt â€“ die HÃ¤lfte hÃ¤tten es hilfreich gefunden, die andere HÃ¤lfte nicht.

Verbesserungspotenzial

Folgende WÃ¼nsche wurden mehrfach genannt:

  • Mehr Praxisbezug und Best Practices â€“ einige wÃ¼nschten sich mehr konkrete Unternehmensbeispiele und Details zu Tools
  • Mehr inhaltliche Tiefe â€“ Wunsch nach konkreteren Aufgaben, Mini-Challenges und detaillierteren Inhalten

Ein konstruktiver Vorschlag wurde dann kurz diskutiert: Die direkte Verlinkung von Podcasts und Blogs zu relevanten Kapiteln im Leitfaden. Denn bei uns gibt es einige Fallstudien und Good-Practices, die wir dokumentiert haben. Dies wÃ¼rde den Mehrwert erhÃ¶hen, ohne groÃŸen zusÃ¤tzlichen Aufwand zu verursachen.

Feedback vom Orga-Team

Wir als Organisatoren stellten zudem fest, dass wir als nicht-teilnehmende Moderatoren weniger Einblick in die Gruppendynamik hatten als in frÃ¼heren Formaten, bei denen wir selbst Mitglieder in Lerngruppen waren. Wir hÃ¤tten uns auch mehr ganz konkretes inhaltliches Feedback zum Leitfaden gewÃ¼nscht. Das bestehende Feedback wird noch voll eingearbeitet.

Ihr kÃ¶nnt direkt im Leitfaden auf GitHub auf den jeweiligen Seiten unten das Feedback einarbeiten.

Die Organisation war weniger aufwÃ¤ndig als erwartet - die Hauptarbeit und Dynamik fanden in den Gruppen selbst statt, die Steuerung von auÃŸen war gering.

Die Teilnehmenden haben wir als Ã¼berwiegend engagiert wahrgenommen. Die DurchfÃ¼hrung mit nur einem Thema und in einer Sprache (Deutsch) war einfach und effizient. FrÃ¼her hatten wir Lernzirkel einmal zu verschiedenen Themen weltweit â€“ was aufgrund der Sprachen und Zeitzonen viel komplexer und aufwÃ¤ndiger.

Inspirierende Aussagen aus der Session

Durchs Tun kommt man auf immer mehr Ideen, was man noch machen kann." (Simon DÃ¼ckert zum KI-Einsatz)

"Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist ein wichtiges Drehkreuz, weil man damit die Beteiligten entsprechend einbindet â€“ das ist WertschÃ¤tzung den Menschen gegenÃ¼ber und keine Excel-Liste." (Michael Kallus)

"Die grÃ¶ÃŸte Lernerfahrung kommt im Austausch. Der Leitfaden ist wie ein Trainingsplan, aber die Laufgruppe macht den Unterschied." (Synthese der Diskussion)

"SAP einfÃ¼hren ist wichtig, aber am Ende, wenn es der Mensch nicht mitnimmt, dann ist die Transformation nicht gelungen." (Adelheid)

"Jedes Projekt ist etwas anders und hat andere Knackpunkte. Der Austausch und andere Sichtweisen zu hÃ¶ren sind enorm hilfreich.â€œ (Teilnehmenden-Feedback)

VerfÃ¼gbare Ressourcen und nÃ¤chste Schritte

Kommt in unsere SAP Training & Change Community!!

Die Community bietet mehrere Formate: monatliche "Kaffeeecken" mit ImpulsvortrÃ¤gen und Austausch, LinkedIn-Gruppe, SAP Community-Bereich sowie den EducationNewscast-Podcast mit Fallstudien. Hier die Links: 

  • LinkedIn Gruppe mit regelmÃ¤ÃŸigen Updates  - SAP Community Gruppe zu OCM mit vielen Blogs
  • Monatlich virtuelle Kaffee Ecke rund um Learning, Change, Adoption

HÃ¶rt in unseren Podcast auf Spotify  oder Apple Podcasts rein â€“ hier gibt es auch immer Change als Thema. entry.title: Luxembourg eCDF - Generate Financial Statement (RPFILU_AFS)
entry.content:
Hello, 

when I generate eCDF XML file in the Generate Financial Statement - Luxembourg (RPFILU_AFS), the values for <Agent> and <Declarer> section are the default ones provided by SAP. 

How can they be changed? Please note that I did the configuration in the SSCUI 101071 Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting in CBC where I defined the LU_EVATECDF_DECL_... and LU_EVATECDF_SEND_... attributes. But unfortunately it only displays in VAT reports via Run statutory Reports app, but not in RPFILU_AFS. 

Where can I maintain the Electronic Financial Data Collection Platform parameters? 

Many thanks

entry.title: Re: Implementing SAP BTP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI - enabling SSO and MFA with corporate IdP
entry.content:
Thanks we figured it out, the SETENV variable was somehow missed, it was set on the servers that did work in the PoC and not on the others. A miscommunication with our technical team.

Very glad to have Kerberos and X.509 working in parralel thanks to this blog!

PS Sorry to hear about your lost access.
